message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cola-colored urine and abdominal pain suggest glomerulonephritis. The boy also has wheals on his body, suggesting urticarial rash, which can be caused by an autoimmune reaction. Elevated levels of serum IgA are associated with Henoch-Schönlein purpura, which presents with glomerulonephritis, joint pain, and skin rash. 24-hour urinary protein is associated with proteinuria, which may be related to glomerulonephritis, but it is not specific. Elevated levels of serum IgG and C3 protein are associated with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, but the boy only had a sore throat and no evidence of recent infection. Elevated IgM-IgG immune complex rheumatoid factors are not specific for any specific disease. Therefore, (B) Elevated level of serum IgA is the most likely associated laboratory finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the cola-colored urine and pain in the ankles suggest acute glomerulonephritis. Elevated levels of serum IgA is associated with this condition. Option A, 24-hour urinary protein of more than 4 g is associated with nephrotic syndrome, which usually presents with edema, not ankle pain or wheals. Option C, elevated IgM-IgG immune complex rheumatoid factor is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, which does not present with cola-colored urine or skin lesions. Option D, elevated levels of serum IgG and C3 protein is non-specific and does not help diagnose a specific condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by a streptococcal infection like the sore throat he had 2 weeks ago. The skin lesions also suggest an immune response. Among the options, only an elevated level of serum IgA is associated with glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests that the patient has Henoch-Schonlein purpura, which typically presents with a triad of joint pain, abdominal pain, and skin rash. The cola-colored urine is also suggestive of hematuria. Elevated levels of serum IgA have been associated with this condition. The other options are not typically associated with Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, including cola-colored urine, pain in the ankles, wheals, and abdominal pain, suggests the most likely diagnosis is IgA nephropathy, which is associated with elevated levels of serum IgA. Option A, 24-hour urinary protein of more than 4 g, is associated with nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Option C, elevated IgM-IgG immune complex rheumatoid factor, is associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Option D, elevated levels of serum IgG and C3 protein, are associated with autoimmune diseases such as lupus and mixed connective tissue disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, including the dark urine, joint pain, and skin lesions, suggests Henoch-Schonlein purpura. This disorder is associated with elevated levels of serum IgA. The other options are not characteristic of this disorder. Option A may be seen in nephrotic syndrome, option C may be seen in rheumatoid arthritis, and option D is not specific to any disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an acute glomerulonephritis secondary to a poststreptococcal infection. The skin lesions suggest an association with streptococcal pharyngitis or impetigo. Among the options, only elevated levels of serum IgA are associated with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Elevated levels of serum IgG and C3 proteins are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, 24-hour urinary protein of more than 4 g is associated with nephrotic syndrome, and elevated IgM-IgG immune complex rheumatoid factor is associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s clinical presentation, including cola-colored urine, ankle pain, abdominal pain, and skin lesions known as urticarial rash, suggest Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP). HSP is associated with elevated levels of serum IgA. The other laboratory findings listed are not associated with HSP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and musculoskeletal findings suggest a possible diagnosis of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP). Elevated levels of serum IgA are often seen in HSP, making option B the most likely laboratory finding associated with this patient's clinical presentation. Options A, C, and D are not typically associated with HSP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). Among the options, an elevated level of serum IgA is the most commonly associated laboratory finding in HSP. Elevated IgM-IgG immune complex rheumatoid factor is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, and elevated levels of serum IgG and C3 protein are seen in lupus nephritis. A 24-hour urinary protein of more than 4g is seen in nephrotic syndrome.
